z:row.TitlePrimary: On some dyadic models of the Euler equations
z:row.Keyword: Euler equations|Burgers equation|Navier-Stokes equations|finite time blow-up|Mathematics, Applied|Mathematics
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PROVIDENCE; 201 CHARLES ST, PROVIDENCE, RI 02940-2213 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Waleffe, F, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; waleffe@math.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: Katz and Pavlovic recently proposed a dyadic model of the Euler equations for which they proved finite time blow-up in the H3/2+epsilon Sobolev norm. It is shown that their model can be reduced to a dyadic model of the inviscid Burgers equation. The inviscid Burgers equation exhibits finite time blow-up in H-alpha, for alpha >= 1/2, but its dyadic restriction is even more singular, exhibiting blow-up for any alpha > 0. Friedlander and Pavlovic developed a closely related model for which they also prove finite time blow-up in H3/2+epsilon. Some inconsistent assumptions in the construction of their model are outlined. Finite time blow-up in the H-alpha norm, for any alpha > 0, is proven for a class of models that includes all those models. An alternative shell model of the Navier-Stokes equations is discussed.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BIFERALE L, 2003, ANNU REV FLUID MECH, V35, P441 DINABURG EI, 2001, MOSCOW MATH J, V1, P381 DINABURG EI, 2003, PROBL INF TRANS, V39 FRIEDLANDER S, 2004, COMMUN PUR APPL MATH, V57, P705 FRISCH U, 1995, TURBULENCE LEGACY AN KATZ NH, 2005, T AM MATH SOC, V357, P695 OBUKHOV AM, 1971, AKAD NAUK SSSR IZV S, V7, P695 WALEFFE F, 2004, ARXIVMATHAP0409310; NR: 8; TC: 0; J9: PROC AMER MATH SOC; PG: 10; GA: 053QX

z:row.TitlePrimary: A new property of a class of Jacobi polynomials
z:row.Keyword: Jacobi and Bessel polynomials|stability|real zeros of polynomials|Mathematics, Applied|Mathematics
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the American Mathematical Society
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PROVIDENCE; 201 CHARLES ST, PROVIDENCE, RI 02940-2213 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Hawaii, Dept Math, Honolulu, HI 96822 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Csordas, G, Univ Hawaii, Dept Math, Honolulu, HI 96822 USA.; george@math.hawaii.edu charalam@math.wisc.edu waleffe@math.wisc.edu
z:row.Abstract: Polynomials whose coefficients are successive derivatives of a class of Jacobi polynomials evaluated at x = 1 are stable. This yields a novel and short proof of the known result that the Bessel polynomials are stable polynomials. Stability-preserving linear operators are discussed. The paper concludes with three open problems involving the distribution of zeros of polynomials.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: ABRAMOWITZ M, 1965, HDB MATH FUNCTIONS ANDREWS GE, 1999, ENCY MATH APPL, V71 CANUTO C, 1988, SPECTRAL METHODS FLU CHIHARA TS, 1978, MATH APPL, V13 CRAVEN T, IN PRESS VALUE DISTR CRAVEN T, 1983, T AM MATH SOC, V278, P415 CRAVEN T, 1995, METHODS APPL ANAL, V2, P420 ERDELYI A, 1953, HIGHER TRANSCENDENTA, V1 GARLOFF J, 1996, J MATH ANAL APPL, V202, P797 GOTTLIEB D, 1981, MATH COMPUT, V36, P107 GOTTLIEB D, 1983, SIAM J NUMER ANAL, V20, P909 GROSSWALD E, 1978, LECT NOTES MATH, V698 HOLTZ O, 2003, LINEAR ALGEBRA APPL, V372, P105 HOVSTAD RM, 1989, P AM MATH SOC, V105, P76 LEVIN BJ, 1964, TRANSL MATH MONO, V5 MARDEN M, 1966, MATH SURVEYS, V3 MASON JC, 2003, CHEBYSHEV POLYNOMIAL OBRESCHKOFF N, 1963, VERTEILUNG BERECHNUN POLYA G, 1974, COLLECTED PAPERS, V2 RAINVILLE E, 1960, SPECIAL FUNCTIONS RIVLIN TJ, 1990, CHEBYSHEV POLYNOMIAL SZEGO, 1975, AM MATH SOC C PUB, V23 WALEFFE F, 2003, PHYS FLUIDS, V15, P1517; NR: 23; TC: 0; J9: PROC AMER MATH SOC; PG: 10; GA: 957GP

z:row.TitlePrimary: Polymer drag reduction in exact coherent structures of plane shear flow (vol 16, pg 3470, 2004)
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA

z:row.TitlePrimary: Experimental observation of nonlinear traveling waves in turbulent pipe flow
z:row.Keyword: EXACT COHERENT STRUCTURES|PLANE COUETTE-FLOW|SHEAR FLOWS|TRANSITION|Multidisciplinary Sciences
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WASHINGTON; 1200 NEW YORK AVE, NW, WASHINGTON, DC 20005 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Delft Univ Technol, Lab Aerodynam & Hydrodynam, NL-2628 CA Delft, Netherlands. Univ Marburg, Fachbereich Phys, D-35032 Marburg, Germany. Univ Bristol, Dept Math, Bristol BS8 1TW, Avon, England. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. U(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Transition to turbulence in pipe flow is one of the most fundamental and longest-standing problems in fluid dynamics. Stability theory suggests that the flow remains laminar for all flow rates, but in practice pipe flow becomes turbulent even at moderate speeds. This transition drastically affects the transport efficiency of mass, momentum, and heat. On the basis of the recent discovery of unstable traveling waves in computational studies of the Navier-stokes equations and ideas from dynamical systems theory, a model, for the transition process has been suggested. We report experimental observation of these traveling waves in pipe flow, confirming the proposed transition scenario and suggesting that the dynamics associated with these unstable states may indeed capture the nature of fluid turbulence.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: CHOI H, 1994, J FLUID MECH, V262, P75 CLEVER RM, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V344, P137 DARBYSHIRE AG, 1995, J FLUID MECH, V289, P83 DRAAD AA, 1998, J FLUID MECH, V377, P267 DRAZIN PG, 1981, HYDRODYNAMIC STABILI ECKHARDT B, 1999, PHYS REV E, V60, P509 EGGELS JGM, 1994, J FLUID MECH, V268, P175 FAISST H, 2003, PHYS REV LETT, V91 FAISST H, 2004, J FLUID MECH, V504, P343 HAMILTON JM, 1995, J FLUID MECH, V287, P317 HOF B, 2003, PHYS REV LETT, V91 KAWAHARA G, 2001, J FLUID MECH, V449, P291 NAGATA M, 1990, J FLUID MECH, V217, P519 PFENINGER W, 1961, BOUNDARY LAYER FLOW, P970 PRASAD AK, 2000, EXP FLUIDS, V29, P103 PROCACCIA I, 1988, NATURE, V333, P498 REYNOLDS O, 1883, P R SOC LONDON, V35, P84 SCHMIEGEL A, 1997, PHYS REV LETT, V79, P5250 SHINBROT T, 1993, NATURE, V363, P411 VANDOOME CWH, 2003, P EUROPIV, V2 VANDOORNE CWH, 2004, THESIS DELFT U TECHN WALEFFE F, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P883 WALEFFE F, 1998, PHYS REV LETT, V81, P4140 WALEFFE F, 2001, J FLUID MECH, V435, P93 WALEFFE F, 2003, PHYS FLUIDS, V15, P1517 WEDIN H, 2004, J FLUID MECH, V508, P333 WYGNANSKI IJ, 1973, J FLUID MECH, V59, P281; NR: 27; TC: 25; J9: SCIENCE; PG: 5; GA: 854GV

z:row.TitlePrimary: Polymer drag reduction in exact coherent structures of plane shear flow
z:row.Keyword: TURBULENT CHANNEL FLOW|FINITE-AMPLITUDE SOLUTIONS|COUETTE-FLOW|PIPE-FLOW|WALL TURBULENCE|ADDITIVES|MECHANISMS|DYNAMICS|STRESS|LAYER|Mechanics|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Biol & Chem Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Michigan, Dept Chem Engn, Ann Arbor, MI 48109 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Math & Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Graham, MD, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Biol & Chem Engn, Madison, WI 5(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: Recently discovered traveling-wave solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations in plane shear geometries provide model flows for the study of turbulent drag reduction by polymer additives. These solutions, or "exact coherent states" (ECS), qualitatively capture the dominant structure of the near-wall buffer region of shear turbulence, i.e., counter-rotating pairs of streamwise-aligned vortices flanking a low-speed streak in the streamwise velocity. The optimum length scales for the ECS match well the length scales of the turbulent coherent structures and evidence suggests that the ECS underlie the dynamics of these structures. We study here the effect of viscoelasticity on these states. The changes to the velocity field for the viscoelastic ECS, where the FENE-P model calculates the polymer stress, mirror the modifications seen in experiments of fully turbulent flows of polymer solutions at low to moderate levels of drag reduction: drag is reduced, streamwise velocity fluctuations increase while wall-normal fluctuations decrease, and smaller wavelength structures are suppressed. These modifications to the ECS are due to the suppression of the streamwise vortices. The polymer molecules become highly stretched in the wavy, streamwise streaks, where the flow is predominately elongational, then relax as they move from the streaks into and around the streamwise vortices, where the flow is predominately rotational. This relaxation of the polymer molecules produces a force that directly opposes the fluid motion in the vortices, weakening them. Since the pressure fluctuations have their greatest magnitude (i.e., they are most negative) in the cores of the vortices, a reduction in vortex strength leads to a decrease in the magnitude of the pressure fluctuations. The pressure fluctuations redistribute energy from the streamwise velocity fluctuations to the Reynolds shear stress, so a decrease in their magnitude leads to a reduction in turbulent drag. For the viscoelastic ECS, we also find that after the onset of drag reduction (at Weissenberg number, Weapproximate to7) there is a dramatic increase in the critical wall-normal length scale at which the ECS can exist. This sharp increase in length scale mirrors experimental observations and is also consistent with the observed shift to higher Reynolds numbers of the transition to turbulence in polymer solutions. (C) 2004 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Homotopy of exact coherent structures in plane shear flows
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Waleffe, F, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Three- dimensional steady states and traveling wave solutions of the Navier - Stokes equations are computed in plane Couette and Poiseuille flows with both free- slip and no- slip boundary conditions. They are calculated using Newton's method by continuation of solutions that bifurcate from a two- dimensional streaky flow then by smooth transformation ( homotopy) from Couette to Poiseuille flow and from free- slip to no- slip boundary conditions. The structural and statistical connections between these solutions and turbulent flows are illustrated. Parametric studies are performed and the parameters leading to the lowest onset Reynolds numbers are determined. In all cases, the lowest onset Reynolds number corresponds to spanwise periods of about 100 wall units. In particular, the rigid- free plane Poiseuille flow traveling wave arises at Re-tau = 44.2 for L-x(+) = 273.7 and L-z(+) = 105.5, in excellent agreement with observations of the streak spacing. A simple one- dimensional map is proposed to illustrate the possible nature of the " hard'' transition to shear turbulence and connections with the unstable exact coherent structures. (C) 2003 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Toward a structural understanding of turbulent drag reduction: Nonlinear coherent states in viscoelastic shear flows
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Chem Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Stone, PA, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Chem Engn, 1415 Johnson Dr, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Nontrivial steady flows have recently been found that capture the main structures of the turbulent buffer layer. We study the effects of polymer addition on these "exact coherent states" (ECS) in plane Couette flow. Despite the simplicity of the ECS flows, these effects closely mirror those observed experimentally: Structures shift to larger length scales, wall-normal fluctuations are suppressed while streamwise ones are enhanced, and drag is reduced. The mechanism underlying these effects is elucidated. These results suggest that the ECS are closely related to buffer layer turbulence.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BALKOVSKY E, 2000, PHYS REV LETT, V84, P4765 BIRD R, 1987, DYNAMICS POLYM LIQUI, V2 BOTTIN S, 1998, PHYS FLUIDS, V10, P2597 CHERTKOV M, 2000, PHYS REV LETT, V84, P4761 CLEVER RM, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V344, P137 DAVIAUD F, 1992, PHYS REV LETT, V69, P2511 DEANGELIS E, 2002, COMPUT FLUIDS, V31, P495 DEGENNES P, 1990, INTRO POLYM DYNAMICS DENTOONDER JMJ, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V337, P193 DIMITROPOULOS CD, 2001, PHYS FLUIDS, V13, P1016 DONOHUE GL, 1972, J FLUID MECH, V56, P559 DRAAD AA, 1998, J FLUID MECH, V377, P267 ECKHARDT B, 1998, PERSPECTIVE LOOK NON ESCUDIER MP, 1999, J NON-NEWTON FLUID, V81, P197 GIRIMAJI SS, 1990, J FLUID MECH, V220, P427 JIMENEZ J, 2001, J FLUID MECH, V435, P81 KAWAHARA G, 2001, J FLUID MECH, V449, P291 LEAL L, 1990, STRUCTURE TURBULENCE LUMLEY JL, 1969, ANNUAL REVIEWS FLUID, V1, P367 LUMLEY JL, 1972, S MATHEMATICA, V9, P315 MCCOMB W, 1990, PHYSICS FLUID TURBUL NAGATA M, 1990, J FLUID MECH, V217, P519 ROBINSON SK, 1991, ANNU REV FLUID MECH, V23, P601 RYSKIN G, 1987, PHYS REV LETT, V59, P2059 SIBILLA S, 2002, PHYS FLUIDS, V14, P1123 SREENIVASAN KR, 2000, J FLUID MECH, V409, P149 STROGATZ SH, 1994, NONLINEAR DYNAMICS C SURESHKUMAR R, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P743 TABOR M, 1986, EUROPHYS LETT, V2, P519 VIRK PS, 1975, AICHE J, V21, P625 WALEFFE F, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P883 WALEFFE F, 1998, PHYS REV LETT, V81, P4140 WALEFFE F, 2001, J FLUID MECH, V435, P93 WALKER DT, 1990, J FLUID MECH, V218, P377; NR: 34; TC: 9; J9: PHYS REV LETT; PG: 4; GA: 610AL

z:row.TitlePrimary: Generation of slow large scales in forced rotating stratified turbulence
z:row.Keyword: ATMOSPHERIC WAVENUMBER SPECTRA|FAST GRAVITY-WAVES|3-DIMENSIONAL|TURBULENCE|COMMERCIAL AIRCRAFT|GEOPHYSICAL FLOWS|INVERSE CASCADE|ENERGY|TRANSFERS|EQUATIONS|DYNAMICS|Mechanics|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: NEW YORK; 40 WEST 20TH ST, NEW YORK, NY 10011-4221 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Smith, LM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Numerical simulations are used to study homogeneous, forced turbulence in three-dimensional rotating, stably stratified flow in the Boussinesq approximation, where the rotation axis and gravity are both in the (z) over cap -direction. Energy is injected through a three-dimensional isotropic white-noise forcing localized at small scales. The parameter range studied corresponds to Froude numbers smaller than an O(1) critical value, below which energy is transferred to scales larger than the forcing scales. The values of the ratio N/f range from approximate to 1/2 to infinity, where N is the Brunt-Vaisala frequency and f is twice the rotation rate. For strongly stratified flows (N/f much greater than 1), the slow large scales generated by the fast small-scale forcing consist of vertically sheared horizontal flow. Quasi-geostrophic dynamics dominate, at large scales, only when 1/2 less than or equal to N/f less than or equal to 2, which is the range where resonant triad interactions cannot occur.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BARTELLO P, 1995, J ATMOS SCI, V52, P4410 BARTELLO P, 1998, GEOPHYSICAL ASTROPHY CAMBON C, 2001, EUR J MECH B-FLUID, V4, P489 CANUTO C, 1988, SPECTRAL METHODS FLU CHARNEY JG, 1971, J ATMOS SCI, V28, P1087 CHASNOV JR, 1994, PHYS FLUIDS, V6, P1036 CHEKHLOV A, 1996, PHYSICA D, V98, P321 EMBID PF, 1996, COMMUN PART DIFF EQ, V21, P619 EMBID PF, 1998, GEOPHYS ASTRO FLUID, V87, P1 GAGE KS, 1986, J ATMOS SCI, V43, P729 GODEFERD FS, 1994, PHYS FLUIDS, V6, P2084 GREENSPAN HP, 1969, J FLUID MECH, V36, P257 HASSELMANN K, 1976, TELLUS, V28, P473 HERRING JR, 1989, J FLUID MECH, V202, P97 HUANG HP, 2000, PHYS FLUIDS, V13, P225 JULIEN K, 1998, THEOR COMP FLUID DYN, V11, P251 KRAICHNAN RH, 1967, PHYS FLUIDS, V10, P1417 LELONG MP, 1991, J FLUID MECH, V232, P1 LILLY DK, 1983, J ATMOS SCI, V40, P749 LILLY DK, 1989, J ATMOS SCI, V46, P2026 LILLY DK, 1998, THEOR COMP FLUID DYN, V11, P139 LONGUETHIGGINS MS, 1967, P ROY SOC LOND A MAT, V299, P120 MAJDA AJ, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P2932 MAJDA AJ, 1998, THEOR COMP FLUID DYN, V11, P155 MAJDA AJ, 1999, P NATL ACAD SCI USA, V96, P14687 MALTRUD ME, 1991, J FLUID MECH, V228, P321 MCWILLIAMS JC, 1994, SCIENCE, V264, P410 METAIS O, 1996, DYNAM ATMOS OCEANS, V23, P193 NASTROM GD, 1985, J ATMOS SCI, V42, P950 PARET J, 1998, PHYS FLUIDS, V10, P3126 PHILLIPS OM, 1968, J FLUID MECH, V34, P407 RILEY JJ, 2000, ANNU REV FLUID MECH, V32, P613 ROGALLO RS, 1981, 81835 NASA SALMON R, 1998, LECT GEOPHYSICAL FLU SMITH LM, 1994, J FLUID MECH, V274, P115 SMITH LM, 1996, PHYS REV LETT, V77, P2467 SMITH LM, 1999, PHYS FLUIDS, V11, P1608 SMITH LM, 2001, ADV WAVE INTERACTION STAQUET C, 1998, J FLUID MECH, V360, P295 VINCENT DG, 1979, TELLUS, V31, P493 WALEFFE F, 1993, PHYS FLUIDS A-FLUID, V5, P677 WARN T, 1986, TELLUS A, V38, P1; NR: 42; TC: 19; J9: J FLUID MECH; PG: 24; GA: 522HW

z:row.TitlePrimary: Exact coherent structures in channel flow
z:row.Keyword: PLANE COUETTE-FLOW|SELF-SUSTAINING PROCESS|NEAR-WALL TURBULENCE|SHEAR FLOWS|STABILITY|TRANSITION|Mechanics|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: PORT CHESTER; 110 MIDLAND AVE, PORT CHESTER, NY 10573-9863 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Waleffe, F, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, 819 Van Vleck Hall, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Exact coherent states in no-slip plane Poiseuille flow are calculated by homotopy from free-slip to no-slip boundary conditions. These coherent states are unstable travelling waves. They consist of wavy low-speed streaks flanked by staggered streamwise vortices closely resembling the asymmetric coherent structures observed in the near-wall region of turbulent flows. The travelling waves arise from a saddle-node bifurcation at a sub-turbulent Reynolds number with wall-normal, spanwise and streamwise dimensions smaller than but comparable to 50(+), 100(+) and 250(+), respectively. These coherent solutions come in pairs with distinct structure and instabilities. There is a three-dimensional continuum of such exact coherent states.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transfer of energy to two-dimensional large scales in forced, rotating three-dimensional turbulence
z:row.Keyword: FAST GRAVITY-WAVES|STRATIFIED TURBULENCE|3-DIMENSIONAL TURBULENCE|GEOPHYSICAL FLOWS|ROSSBY WAVES|BETA-PLANE|ADJUSTMENT|GENERATION|DYNAMICS|CASCADES|Mechanics|Physics, Fluids & Plasmas
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: WOODBURY; CIRCULATION FULFILLMENT DIV, 500 SUNNYSIDE BLVD, WOODBURY, NY 11797-2999 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Mech Engn, Madison, WI 53706 USA. Univ Wisconsin, Dept Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Smith, LM, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Forced turbulence in a rotating frame is studied using numerical simulations in a triply periodic box. The random forcing is three dimensional and localized about an intermediate wavenumber k(f). The results show that energy is transferred to scales larger than the forcing scale when the rotation rate is large enough. The scaling of the energy spectrum approaches E(k) proportional to k(-3) for k < k(f). Almost all of the energy for k < k(f) lies in the two-dimensional (2D) plane perpendicular to the rotation z-axis, and thus the large-scale motions an quasi-2D with E(k) approximate to E(k(h), k(z) = 0), where k(h) and k(z) are, respectively, the horizontal and vertical components of the wavevector. The large scales consist of cyclonic vortices. Possible mechanisms responsible for the two-dimensionalization are discussed. The development of the 2D spectrum E(k(h), k(z) = 0) proportional to k(h)(-3) is analogous to the dynamics of beta-plane turbulence leading to the Rhines spectrum E(k(y), k(x) = 0) proportional to k(y)(-5). (C) 1999 American Institute of Physics. [S1070-6631(99)00706-0].
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BABIN A, 1998, THEOR COMP FLUID DYN, V11, P215 BARTELLO P, 1995, J ATMOS SCI, V52, P4410 BENNEY DJ, 1966, P ROY SOC LOND A MAT, V289, P301 BENNEY DJ, 1969, STUD APPL MATH, V48, P29 BENZI R, 1996, PHYS REV E A, V53, P3541 CAMBON C, 1989, J FLUID MECH, V202, P295 CAMBON C, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V337, P303 CANUTO C, 1988, SPECTRAL METHODS FLU CANUTO C, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P2132 CHASNOV JR, 1995, COMMUNICATION CHEKHLOV A, 1996, PHYSICA D, V98, P321 EMBID PF, 1996, COMMUN PART DIFF EQ, V21, P619 EMBID PF, 1998, GEOPHYS ASTRO FLUID, V87, P1 GODEFERD FS, 1994, PHYS FLUIDS, V6, P2084 GREENSPAN HP, 1968, THEORY ROTATING FLUI GREENSPAN HP, 1969, J FLUID MECH, V36, P257 HERRING JR, 1988, METEOROL ATMOS PHYS, V38, P106 HERRING JR, 1989, J FLUID MECH, V202, P97 HOLLOWAY G, 1977, J FLUID MECH, V82, P747 HOPFINGER EJ, 1982, J FLUID MECH, V125, P505 KRAICHNAN RH, 1967, PHYS FLUIDS, V10, P1417 KRIACHNAN RH, 1971, J FLUID MECH, V47, P525 LELONG MP, 1991, J FLUID MECH, V232, P1 LONGUETHIGGINS MS, 1967, P ROY SOC LOND A MAT, V299, P120 MAJDA AJ, 1997, J NONLINEAR SCI, V6, P9 MAJDA AJ, 1998, THEOR COMP FLUID DYN, V11, P155 METAIS O, 1996, DYNAM ATMOS OCEANS, V23, P193 MILEWSKI PA, 1995, STUD APPL MATH, V94, P131 NEWELL AC, 1969, J FLUID MECH, V35, P255 PEDLOSKY J, 1979, GEOPHYSICAL FLUID DY PHILLIPS OM, 1968, J FLUID MECH, V34, P407 RHINES PB, 1975, J FLUID MECH, V69, P417 RUBINSTEIN R, UNPUB DOUBLE RESONAN RUBINSTEIN R, 1997, 9763 ICASE RUTGERS MA, 1998, PHYS REV LETT, V81, P2244 SALMON R, 1998, LECT GEOPHYSICAL FLU SMITH LM, 1993, PHYS REV LETT, V71, P352 SMITH LM, 1994, J FLUID MECH, V274, P115 SMITH LM, 1996, PHYS REV LETT, V77, P2467 SOOMERE T, 1993, ANN GEOPHYS, V11, P90 VALLIS GK, 1993, J PHYS OCEANOGR, V23, P1346 WALEFFE F, 1992, PHYS FLUIDS A-FLUID, V4, P350 WALEFFE F, 1993, PHYS FLUIDS A-FLUID, V5, P677 WARN T, 1986, TELLUS A, V38, P1 ZAKHAROV VE, 1992, WAVE TURBULENCE ZHOU Y, 1995, PHYS FLUIDS, V7, P2092; NR: 46; TC: 38; J9: PHYS FLUIDS; PG: 15; GA: 197UL

z:row.TitlePrimary: Three-dimensional coherent states in plane shear flows
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math & Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.; Waleffe, F, Univ Wisconsin, Dept Math & Engn Phys, Madison, WI 53706 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Three-dimensional steady states in plane Couette flow and traveling-wave solutions in plane Poiseuille flow are calculated for stress boundary conditions. The procedure is tied to a self-sustaining mechanism associated with the coherent structures that have been observed in turbulent shear flows. The exact states in both types of flow are remarkably similar to each other and to the coherent structures. They survive down to Reynolds numbers below the critical value for turbulence onset. These results suggest that the underlying process is generic and fundamental to both transitional and developed turbulence.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BENNEY DJ, 1984, STUD APPL MATH, V70, P1 CLEVER RM, 1992, J FLUID MECH, V234, P511 CLEVER RM, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V344, P137 CONLEY A, 1994, THESIS CALTECH DRAZIN PG, 1981, HYDRODYNAMIC STABILI HAMILTON JM, 1995, J FLUID MECH, V287, P317 JEONG J, 1997, J FLUID MECH, V332, P185 JIMENEZ J, 1993, J FLUID MECH, V248, P297 NAGATA M, 1990, J FLUID MECH, V217, P519 PANTON R, 1997, SELFSUSTAINING MECHA REYNOLDS O, 1883, PHILOS T ROY SOC LON, V174, P935 SCHOPPA W, 1998, P 29 AIAA FLUID DYN STRETCH DD, 1990, ANN RES BRIEFS 1990 WALEFFE F, 1995, PHYS FLUIDS, V7, P3060 WALEFFE F, 1995, STUD APPL MATH, V95, P319 WALEFFE F, 1997, PHYS FLUIDS, V9, P883 WALEFFE F, 1998, P 29 AIAA FLUID DYN; NR: 17; TC: 27; J9: PHYS REV LETT; PG: 4; GA: 139CW

z:row.TitlePrimary: Polymer drag reduction in exact coherent structures of plane shear flow
z:row.Keyword: Shear flow|Turbulent flow|Vortex flow|Fluid dynamics|Viscoelasticity|Stresses|Polymers|Relaxation processes|Reynolds number|Turbulence
z:row.Publisher: American Institute of Physics Inc., Melville, NY 11747-4502, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Chemical/Biol. Eng., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706-1607, United States
z:row.Abstract: Recently discovered traveling-wave solutions to the Navier-Stokes equations in plane shear geometries provide model flows for the study of turbulent drag reduction by polymer additives. These solutions, or "exact coherent states" (ECS), qualitatively capture the dominant structure of the near-wall buffer region of shear turbulence, i.e., counter-rotating pairs of streamwise-aligned vortices flanking a low-speed streak in the streamwise velocity. The optimum length scales for the ECS match well the length scales of the turbulent coherent structures and evidence suggests that the ECS underlie the dynamics of these structures. We study here the effect of viscoelasticity on these states. The changes to the velocity field for the viscoelastic ECS, where the FENE-P model calculates the polymer stress, mirror the modifications seen in experiments of fully turbulent flows of polymer solutions at low to moderate levels of drag reduction: drag is reduced, streamwise velocity fluctuations increase while wall-normal fluctuations decrease, and smaller wavelength structures are suppressed. These modifications to the ECS are due to the suppression of the streamwise vortices. The polymer molecules become highly stretched in the wavy, streamwise streaks, where the flow is predominately elongational, then relax as they move from the streaks into and around the streamwise vortices, where the flow is predominately rotational. This relaxation of the polymer molecules produces a force that directly opposes the fluid motion in the vortices, weakening them. Since the pressure fluctuations have their greatest magnitude (i.e., they are most negative) in the cores of the vortices, a reduction in vortex strength leads to a decrease in the magnitude of the pressure fluctuations. The pressure fluctuations redistribute energy from the streamwise velocity fluctuations to the Reynolds shear stress, so a decrease in their magnitude leads to a reduction in turbulent drag. For the viscoelastic ECS, we also find that after the onset of drag reduction (at Weissenberg number, We approximately equals 7) there is a dramatic increase in the critical wall-normal length scale at which the ECS can exist. This sharp increase in length scale mirrors experimental observations and is also consistent with the observed shift to higher Reynolds numbers of the transition to turbulence in polymer solutions. © 2004 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Vortex strength; Traveling-wave solutions; Turbulent drag

z:row.TitlePrimary: Homotopy of exact coherent structures in plane shear flows
z:row.Keyword: Shear flow|Turbulent flow|Turbulence|Reynolds number|Boundary conditions|Navier Stokes equations
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Depts. of Mathematics/Eng. Physics, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Three-dimensional steady states and traveling wave solutions of the Navier-Stokes equations are computed in plane Couette and Poiseuille flows with both free-slip and no-slip boundary conditions. They are calculated using Newton's method by continuation of solutions that bifurcate from a two-dimensional streaky flow then by smooth transformation (homotopy) from Couette to Poiseuille flow and from free-slip to no-slip boundary conditions. The structural and statistical connections between these solutions and turbulent flows are illustrated. Parametric studies are performed and the parameters leading to the lowest onset Reynolds numbers are determined. In all cases, the lowest onset Reynolds number corresponds to spanwise periods of about 100 wall units. In particular, the rigid-free plane Poiseuille flow traveling wave arises at ReT=44.2 for Lx+ = 273.7 and Lz+ = 105.5, in excellent agreement with observations of the streak spacing. A simple one-dimensional map is proposed to illustrate the possible nature of the "hard" transition to shear turbulence and connections with the unstable exact coherent structures. © 2003 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Toward a structural understanding of turbulent drag reduction: Nonlinear coherent states in viscoelastic shear flows
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Department of Chemical Engineering, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: The effects of polymer addition on the nonlinear exact coherent states (ECS) in viscoelastic shear flow was studied. It was observed that the wall-normal fluctuations were suppressed while streamwise ones were enhanced and drag was reduced. The results showed that the ECS was closely related to buffer layer turbulence.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Generation of slow large scales in forced rotating stratified turbulence
z:row.Publisher: Cambridge University Press, New York, NY 10011-4211, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Mathematics/Mechanical Eng., University of Wisconsin, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Numerical simulations are used to study homogeneous, forced turbulence in three-dimensional rotating, stably stratified flow in the Boussinesq approximation, where the rotation axis and gravity are both in the z-direction. Energy is injected through a three-dimensional isotropic white-noise forcing localized at small scales. The parameter range studied corresponds to Froude numbers smaller than an O(1) critical value, below which energy is transferred to scales larger than the forcing scales. The values of the ratio N/f range from approximately equals 1/2 to infinity , where N is the Brunt-Vaisala frequency and f is twice the rotation rate. For strongly stratified flows (N/f very much greater than 1), the slow large scales generated by the fast small-scale forcing consist of vertically sheared horizontal flow. Quasi-geostrophic dynamics dominate, at large scales, only when 1/2 [less-than or equal to] N/f [less-than or equal to] 2, which is the range where resonant triad interactions cannot occur.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Generation of slow large scales in forced rotating stratified turbulence
z:row.Keyword: eigenvalues and eigenfunctions|flow simulation|rotational flow|stratified flow|turbulence|white noise
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Mech. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Numerical simulations are used to study homogeneous, forced turbulence in three-dimensional rotating, stably stratified flow in the Boussinesq approximation, where the rotation axis and gravity are both in the zˆ-direction. Energy is injected through a three-dimensional isotropic white-noise forcing localized at small scales. The parameter range studied corresponds to Froude numbers smaller than an O(1) critical value, below which energy is transferred to scales larger than the forcing scales. The values of the ratio N/f range from ≈1/2 to ∞, where N is the Brunt-Vaisala frequency and f is twice the rotation rate. For strongly stratified flows (N/f >1), the slow large scales generated by the fast small-scale forcing consist of vertically sheared horizontal flow. Quasi-geostrophic dynamics dominate, at large scales, only when 1/2⩽N/f⩽2, which is the range where resonant triad interactions cannot occur
z:row.User2: slow large scales generation; forced rotating stratified turbulence; numerical simulations; strongly stratified flows; small-scale forcing; vertically sheared horizontal flow; quasi-geostrophic dynamics; resonant triad interactions; Brunt-Vaisala frequency; rotation rate; homogeneous forced turbulence; three-dimensional rotating stably stratified flow; Boussinesq approximation; rotation axis; gravity; oceanic flows; atmospheric flows; linear eigenmodes; vertically stratified flow; rotational flow; buoyancy frequency; inviscid unforced limit; Boussinesq equations; pseudo-spectral code; purely stratified turbulence; Froude number; rotating stratified turbulence; quasi-geostrophic equation; pancake structures; white-in-time random forcing; z-direction; energy injection; three-dimensional isotropic white-noise forcing; localized forcing; small scales

z:row.TitlePrimary: Exact coherent structures in channel flow
z:row.Keyword: Channel flow|Boundary conditions|Vortex flow|Computational complexity|Reynolds number|Turbulent flow|Continuum mechanics|Bifurcation (mathematics)
z:row.Publisher: Cambridge University Press, New York, NY 10011-4211, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Math./Eng. Physics, University of Wisconsin, Madison WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Exact coherent states in no-slip plane Poiseuille flow are calculated by homotopy from free-slip to no-slip boundary conditions. These coherent states are unstable travelling waves. They consist of wavy low-speed streaks flanked by staggered streamwise vortices closely resembling the asymmetric coherent structures observed in the near-wall region of turbulent flows. The travelling waves arise from a saddle-node bifurcation at a sub-turbulent Reynolds number with wall-normal, spanwise and streamwise dimensions smaller than but comparable to 50+, 100+ and 250+, respectively. These coherent solutions come in pairs with distinct structure and instabilities. There is a three-dimensional continuum of such exact coherent states.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Transfer of energy to two-dimensional large scales in forced, rotating three-dimensional turbulence
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Depts. of Math. and Mech. Eng., University of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI 53706, United States
z:row.Abstract: Forced turbulence in a rotating frame is studied using numerical simulations in a triply periodic box. The random forcing is three dimensional and localized about an intermediate wavenumber kf. The results show that energy is transferred to scales larger than the forcing scale when the rotation rate is large enough. The scaling of the energy spectrum approaches E(k) varies directly as k-3 for k less than or equal kf. Almost all of the energy for k less than or equal kf lies in the two-dimensional (2D) plane perpendicular to the rotation z-axis, and thus the large-scale motions are quasi-2D with E(k) approximately equals E(kh,kz = 0), where kh and kz are, respectively, the horizontal and vertical components of the wavevector. The large scales consist of cyclonic vortices. Possible mechanisms responsible for the two-dimensionalization are discussed. The development of the 2D spectrum E(kh,kz=0) varies directly as kh-3 is analogous to the dynamics of β-plane turbulence leading to the Rhines spectrum E(ky,kx = 0) varies directly as ky-5. © 1999 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Three-dimensional coherent states in plane shear flows
z:row.Keyword: Couette flow|laminar to turbulent transitions|Poiseuille flow|shear flow|turbulence
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Math., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Three-dimensional steady states in plane Couette flow and travelling-wave solutions in plane Poiseuille flow are calculated for stress boundary conditions. The procedure is tied to a self-sustaining mechanism associated with the coherent structures that have been observed in turbulent shear flows. The exact states in both types of flow are remarkably similar to each other and to the coherent structures. They survive down to Reynolds numbers below the critical value for turbulence onset. These results suggest that the underlying process is generic and fundamental to both transitional and developed turbulence
z:row.User2: three-dimensional coherent states; plane shear flows; steady states; plane Couette flow; travelling-wave solutions; plane Poiseuille flow; stress boundary conditions; self-sustaining mechanism; coherent structures; turbulent shear flows; turbulence onset; Reynolds numbers; critical value; transitional turbulence; developed turbulence
